references: A distinguishing feature of IDFF is its ability to jointly learn an implicit flow from the generated samples alongside the scoring model, setting it apart from models like DDIM, which focuses solely on learning a scoring function. By leveraging OT to couple samples between t=0𝑡0t=0 and t=1𝑡1t=1, IDFF accelerates convergence during training while maintaining low NFE and improving sample quality. It is evident from our image generation experiments (Tables 1 and 2). In comparisons with DDPM, DDIM, and DPM-Solver (another model that improves the NFEs for diffusion models)Lu et al. (2022a), IDFF consistently demonstrates superior efficiency and quality.

We also examined the effect of σ0subscript𝜎0\sigma_{0} on sample quality for both CIFAR-10 and CelebA datasets in Appendix A.1.3, finding that a value of σ0=0.6subscript𝜎00.6\sigma_{0}=0.6 achieved the best FID for both datasets, as shown in Table 1 and Table 2. IDFF achieves comparable FID scores with ten times fewer NFEs than CFM and DDPM on the CIFAR-10 and CelebA datasets. IDFF’s qualitative results are provided in Figure 1 (additional samples are available in Appendix A.2).

By leveraging OT to couple samples between t=0𝑡0t=0 and t=1𝑡1t=1, IDFF accelerates convergence during training while maintaining low NFE and improving sample quality. It is evident from our image generation experiments (Tables 1 and 2). In comparisons with DDPM, DDIM, and DPM-Solver (another model that improves the NFEs for diffusion models)Lu et al. (2022a), IDFF consistently demonstrates superior efficiency and quality.

We also examined the effect of σ0subscript𝜎0\sigma_{0} on sample quality for both CIFAR-10 and CelebA datasets in Appendix A.1.3, finding that a value of σ0=0.6subscript𝜎00.6\sigma_{0}=0.6 achieved the best FID for both datasets, as shown in Table 1 and Table 2. references: To assess the performance of IDFF in the MD simulation, we utilized several evaluation metrics, including root mean squared error (RMSE), mean absolute error (MAE), and correlation coefficients (CC) between the generated and actual trajectories of dihedral angles. We benchmarked IDFF against well-known dynamical models for time series, including dynamical VAE models such as SRNNs (Fraccaro et al., 2016), VRNNs (Chung et al., 2015), and Neural ODEs (NODEs) (Garnelo et al., 2018). As shown in Table 3, IDFF outperforms the baselines by a large margin, indicating its great potential for simulating molecular dynamics from scratch.

references:
We used a class-conditional UNet (ADM) for the SST experiment, with the class encoder part encoding the long-range time dependencies (i.e., for encoding the days) to allow continuous forecasting using the UNet (ADM). See Appendix A.1.4 for the experiment’s network structure and hyperparameter settings. We used the training 1 and sampling 2 algorithms suggested for time-series data. We evaluated the performance of IDFF using the best validation continuous ranked probability score (CRPS) (Matheson and Winkler, 1976) and mean squared error (MSE) on forecasts up to 7 days. CRPS is a proper scoring rule and a popular metric in probabilistic forecasting literature (Gneiting and Katzfuss, 2014). We calculate the CRPS by generating a 20-member ensemble and the MSE on the ensemble mean predictions in Table 4.
To assess IDFF’s performance, we compared it against various baseline approaches, including DDPM, DDPM with enabled dropout (Dropout) (Gal and Ghahramani, 2016), DDPM with random perturbation for the initial values (Perturbation) (Pathak et al., 2022), MCVD (Voleti et al., 2022), Dyffusion (Cachay et al., 2023), and OT-CFM (with N​F​E=40𝑁𝐹𝐸40NFE=40) as shown in Table 4. The results for all the baselines are with N​F​E=1000𝑁𝐹𝐸1000NFE=1000. These baselines provide a robust framework for evaluating the IDFF framework in time-series forecasting. For more details about the SST dataset and experiment, refer to (Cachay et al., 2023). The results show that IDFF (with N​F​E=5𝑁𝐹𝐸5NFE=5) outperforms the baselines in SST forecasting across both metrics, demonstrating great potential for weather forecasting applications. See samples of the forecasting results in Figure 13.
